description:
Sphaerodactylus townsendi, commonly known as the Townsend's dwarf gecko, is a small species of gecko found in the Caribbean region. It belongs to the genus Sphaerodactylus, which comprises some of the smallest lizards in the world.

The Townsend's dwarf gecko is characterized by its small size, typically measuring around 3-4 inches (7-10 cm) in total length. It has a slender, cylindrical body with a flattened head and large, round eyes. The gecko's toes are broad and slightly webbed, which helps it to climb and adhere to smooth surfaces.

The species is found in the Bahamas, where it inhabits various habitats, including tropical forests, rocky areas, and coastal environments. It is known to be nocturnal and arboreal, spending much of its time hiding in crevices, under bark, or in the leaf litter.

Sphaerodactylus townsendi is an insectivorous species, feeding primarily on small invertebrates, such as insects and spiders. It reproduces through oviparous (egg-laying) means, with females laying a single egg at a time.

The Townsend's dwarf gecko is considered a species of least concern by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) due to its relatively wide distribution and stable population status within its native range.
